question.questionA: Trees or shrubs.
question.questionB: Herbs.

question.questionA: Leaves compound.
question.questionB: Leaves simple.

question.questionA: Carpels free, exposed over the surface of the receptacle.
question.questionB: Carpels enclosed in a fleshy receptacle.

question.questionA: Non-spiny shrubs; petals yellow.
question.questionB: Spiny shrubs; petals white or purple.

question.questionA: Herbaceous  perennials with creeping stems, rooting at the nodes; flowers yellow (see below).
question.questionB: Erect shrubs; flowers white.

question.questionA: Stems strong, arching; leaflets three to five, broad, dark green above, white tomentose below; petals lilac; druplets more than twenty.
question.questionB: Stems weak, straggling; leaflets three; narrow, light green above and below; petals white; druplets fewer than twenty, especially in axillary fruits.

question.questionA: Non-spiny trees; carpels fused to receptacle.
question.questionB: Spiny shrubs; carpels free within receptacle.

question.questionA: Leaves pinnate; inflorescence dense, many-flowered; fruits 20-50 mm, orange-red.
question.questionB: Leaves simple; inflorescence lax, few-flowered; fruits 8-15 mm, scarlet.

question.questionA: Sepals usually entire; styles fused.
question.questionB: Sepals with lateral lobes; styles free.

question.questionA: Trailing shrubs; leaves deciduous; petioles with stalked glands; column of fused styles as long as shortest stamen, styles glabrous.
question.questionB: Erect shrubs; leaves evergreen; petioles eglandular; column of fused styles shorter than smallest stamen, styles hairy.

question.questionA: Abaxial surface either eglandular or with glands restricted to the veins; sepals reflexed, caducous.
question.questionB: Abaxial surface of leaves coated with conspicuous brown, viscid fruit-scented glands.

question.questionA: Leaves cuneate at base; pedicels glabrous.
question.questionB: Leaflets rounded at the base; pedicels glandular-hispid.

question.questionA: Stems erect; prickles usually unequal; styles pilose; sepals not reflexed persistent in fruit.
question.questionB: Stems  arching; prickles more or  less  equal;  styles glabrous;  sepals reflexed, caducous.

question.questionA: Carpels free, exposed over surface of receptacle.
question.questionB: Carpels enclosed in a fleshy receptacle.

question.questionA: Spiny shrub; flowers appearing before the leaves; pericarp softly fleshy with a waxy bloom, not splitting on ripening.
question.questionB: Small tree; flowers appearing after the leaves; pericarp firmly fleshy densely hairy, splitting on ripening to release large seed.

question.questionA: Flowers solitary.
question.questionB: Flowers in clusters of two or more.

question.questionA: Sepals dentate, blunt, shorter than petals.
question.questionB: Sepals entire, long pointed, longer than petals.

question.questionA: Pericarp (n.b. not receptacle) hard and stone-like in fruit.
question.questionB: Pericarp fleshy in fruit but test sometimes hard.

question.questionA: Inflorescence a simple umbel, or few-flowered.
question.questionB: Inflorescence compound, made up of smaller clusters.

question.questionA: Leaves deciduous.
question.questionB: Leaves evergreen.

question.questionA: Petals absent.
question.questionB: Petals present.

question.questionA: Leaves pinnate; stamens four or many.
question.questionB: Leaves simple or palmately divided; stamens one or two.

question.questionA: Procumbent annual; all leaves petiolate; sepals erect in fruit.
question.questionB: Erect annual; upper leaves sessile; sepals spreading in fruit.
